objective: To introduce the idea of selling and buying.
explanation:
• Shops are places where people buy things. 
 • Shopkeepers help us choose and pay. 
 • Some kids also pretend to run shops.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Toy Shop Setup
Materials Needed: Toy fruits, boxes, play money.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a pretend shop with toys.
• Child plays as shopkeeper, you play as buyer.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand role of a shopkeeper.
What is Gained:
• Role play
• Early business idea
steps: Set up a pretend shop with toys.
Child plays as shopkeeper, you play as buyer.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Price Match Game
Materials Needed: Flashcards with items and prices.
Steps to Follow:
• Show item card and ask child to match with correct price.
• Use simple numbers.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect value with items.
What is Gained:
• Number sense
• Item-value link
steps: Show item card and ask child to match with correct price.
Use simple numbers.

objective: To understand making and selling something.
explanation:
• People can make things and sell them. 
 • Lemonade is a simple thing kids can pretend to sell. 
 • Selling teaches sharing and helping.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Pretend Lemonade Stand
Materials Needed: Paper cups, water, yellow paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Child sets up a lemonade stand with pretend items.
• Invite family to “buy.”
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand selling idea.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Social play
steps: Child sets up a lemonade stand with pretend items.
Invite family to “buy.”

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Decorate & Advertise
Materials Needed: Crayons, signs, stickers.
Steps to Follow:
• Make signs to attract customers.
• Decorate stand with fun stickers.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn simple promotion.
What is Gained:
• Art skill
• Early marketing
steps: Make signs to attract customers.
Decorate stand with fun stickers.

objective: To learn about money used in business.
explanation:
• Coins are used to buy and sell. 
 • Different coins have different values. 
 • Entrepreneurs need to understand money.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Coin Sorting
Materials Needed: Plastic or real coins.
Steps to Follow:
• Sort coins by size or color.
• Talk about how coins are used to buy.
What Should Be Achieved:
Recognize money types.
What is Gained:
• Sorting skills
• Money awareness
steps: Sort coins by size or color.
Talk about how coins are used to buy.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Coin Store Game
Materials Needed: Coins, small toys.
Steps to Follow:
• Set price for each toy.
• Child “buys” with coins.
What Should Be Achieved:
Use money in pretend buying.
What is Gained:
• Counting
• Decision-making
steps: Set price for each toy.
Child “buys” with coins.

objective: To introduce the idea of building a small market.
explanation:
• Markets are places with many small sellers. 
 • Each box can be a shop with items. 
 • Kids can learn to organize and display.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Market Setup
Materials Needed: Cardboard boxes, toys, cloth pieces.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up different box stalls.
• Each stall has something to “sell.”
What Should Be Achieved:
Build small market stalls.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Sorting and setup
steps: Set up different box stalls.
Each stall has something to “sell.”

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Market Walk
Materials Needed: Paper bag or basket.
Steps to Follow:
• Child walks around choosing items.
• Practice saying “How much?” or “Thank you.”
What Should Be Achieved:
Role-play buying in a market.
What is Gained:
• Speaking skills
• Social behavior
steps: Child walks around choosing items.
Practice saying “How much?” or “Thank you.”

objective: To explore the idea of exchanging things.
explanation:
• People trade when they don’t use money. 
 • You give something and get something back. 
 • Fair trade helps everyone.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Toy Swap
Materials Needed: Two sets of toys.
Steps to Follow:
• Offer one toy and ask for a trade.
• Talk about why the trade is fair.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand equal value.
What is Gained:
• Fairness
• Decision making
steps: Offer one toy and ask for a trade.
Talk about why the trade is fair.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Snack Trade
Materials Needed: Two kinds of snacks.
Steps to Follow:
• Trade snack types with each other.
• Discuss if both are happy with it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice real trade.
What is Gained:
• Sharing
• Negotiation
steps: Trade snack types with each other.
Discuss if both are happy with it.

objective: To introduce the concept of having business ideas.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs start with ideas. 
 • An idea can be a toy, game, or service. 
 • Even kids can think of fun ideas.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
What's Your Idea?
Materials Needed: Small box, paper slips.
Steps to Follow:
• Ask child to think of fun things to “sell.”
• Write or draw ideas and put in the box.
What Should Be Achieved:
Think creatively about business.
What is Gained:
• Idea generation
• Confidence
steps: Ask child to think of fun things to “sell.”
Write or draw ideas and put in the box.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pick & Act
Materials Needed: Idea slips from box.
Steps to Follow:
• Pick a slip and act it out.
• Pretend to make or sell the idea.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect idea to action.
What is Gained:
• Expression
• Imagination
steps: Pick a slip and act it out.
Pretend to make or sell the idea.

objective: To understand the importance of customers.
explanation:
• Customers are people who buy. 
 • Good sellers listen and help. 
 • Happy customers return.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Be a Helpful Seller
Materials Needed: Toy items, basket.
Steps to Follow:
• Child pretends to sell.
• You ask for help and smile if they help.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn polite seller behavior.
What is Gained:
• Social skills
• Empathy
steps: Child pretends to sell.
You ask for help and smile if they help.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Happy Shopper
Materials Needed: Simple token or sticker.
Steps to Follow:
• Give a sticker if child is polite while selling.
• Celebrate good service.
What Should Be Achieved:
Encourage care in selling.
What is Gained:
• Reward motivation
• Manners
steps: Give a sticker if child is polite while selling.
Celebrate good service.

objective: To show how people make and sell services.
explanation:
• Not all entrepreneurs sell things—some build or help. 
 • Services include cleaning, fixing, or teaching. 
 • Helping others is a kind of work too.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Fix-It Pretend
Materials Needed: Toy tools, broken toy.
Steps to Follow:
• Pretend to fix the broken toy.
• Act like a builder or fixer.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand service as business.
What is Gained:
• Helping habit
• Motor skill
steps: Pretend to fix the broken toy.
Act like a builder or fixer.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Helper Badge
Materials Needed: Paper badge, tape.
Steps to Follow:
• Give a badge when child helps fix or clean.
• Pretend they earned it like a helper.
What Should Be Achieved:
Value of small services.
What is Gained:
• Responsibility
• Self-worth
steps: Give a badge when child helps fix or clean.
Pretend they earned it like a helper.

objective: To recognize money as something people use.
explanation:
• Money can be coins or paper. 
 • Some money looks different in color and size. 
 • It helps us pay and trade.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Make Play Money
Materials Needed: Colored paper, scissors.
Steps to Follow:
• Cut paper into notes.
• Draw numbers and symbols.
What Should Be Achieved:
Create pretend money.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Recognition
steps: Cut paper into notes.
Draw numbers and symbols.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Use It to Buy
Materials Needed: Play money and toys.
Steps to Follow:
• Use created money to buy toys in pretend play.
• Practice paying and receiving.
What Should Be Achieved:
Link money to buying.
What is Gained:
• Math start
• Business logic
steps: Use created money to buy toys in pretend play.
Practice paying and receiving.

objective: To learn how businesses tell people about their products.
explanation:
• Ads help people know what’s for sale. 
 • You can draw, talk, or act to advertise. 
 • Creative ads attract buyers.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Draw an Ad
Materials Needed: Crayons, paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Draw a poster showing your pretend shop or product.
• Hang it up proudly.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand basic promotion.
What is Gained:
• Art expression
• Promotion skill
steps: Draw a poster showing your pretend shop or product.
Hang it up proudly.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Talk Show Seller
Materials Needed: A toy product.
Steps to Follow:
• Pretend you’re on TV selling the product.
• Say why it’s great and useful.
What Should Be Achieved:
Speak confidently about product.
What is Gained:
• Public speaking
• Product thinking
steps: Pretend you’re on TV selling the product.
Say why it’s great and useful.

objective: To help children learn about simple business ideas.
explanation:
• A lemonade stand is a tiny business. 
 • It sells drinks to people. 
 • It teaches how to offer something useful.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Lemonade Stand Play
Materials Needed: Toy cups, play money, juice or pretend lemonade.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a pretend lemonade stall.
• Invite family to “buy.”
• Use play money to sell.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand buying and selling.
What is Gained:
• Social skills
• Business basics
steps: Set up a pretend lemonade stall.
Invite family to “buy.”
Use play money to sell.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Sell Me Something
Materials Needed: Toys or small items.
Steps to Follow:
• Choose a toy to “sell.”
• Explain why someone should buy it.
• Practice “selling.”
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice persuasion.
What is Gained:
• Communication
• Confidence
steps: Choose a toy to “sell.”
Explain why someone should buy it.
Practice “selling.”

objective: To teach the concept of saving money.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs save money to use later. 
 • A jar is a simple way to save. 
 • Saving helps in buying something bigger later.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Save and Watch
Materials Needed: Jar, play coins.
Steps to Follow:
• Add coins to the jar daily.
• Watch it fill up.
• Talk about saving.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand basic saving.
What is Gained:
• Patience
• Goal setting
steps: Add coins to the jar daily.
Watch it fill up.
Talk about saving.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Picture Your Goal
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Draw what you want to save for.
• Place it on or near the jar.
• Talk about how saving gets you closer.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect saving to goals.
What is Gained:
• Motivation
• Visual thinking
steps: Draw what you want to save for.
Place it on or near the jar.
Talk about how saving gets you closer.

objective: To show how everyday things can become a business.
explanation:
• Businesses often begin with small ideas. 
 • A simple craft or treat can be shared. 
 • Kids can learn to think of ideas.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
What Can This Be?
Materials Needed: Everyday items like bottle caps, boxes, straws.
Steps to Follow:
• Show an item and ask “What could we make with this?”
• Let child build something new.
• Talk about its use.
What Should Be Achieved:
Creative product thinking.
What is Gained:
• Innovation
• Imagination
steps: Show an item and ask “What could we make with this?”
Let child build something new.
Talk about its use.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pretend Product Pitch
Materials Needed: Toy microphone or cardboard tube.
Steps to Follow:
• Pretend to “sell” the created item.
• Talk about what it does.
• Use imagination.
What Should Be Achieved:
Share ideas clearly.
What is Gained:
• Confidence
• Public speaking
steps: Pretend to “sell” the created item.
Talk about what it does.
Use imagination.

objective: To teach about sharing and kindness in business.
explanation:
• Some businesses also help people. 
 • Giving and kindness are part of good entrepreneurship. 
 • You can “sell” for free!

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Gift Shop Roleplay
Materials Needed: Old toys or books, paper bags.
Steps to Follow:
• Set up a pretend shop.
• Invite family to choose an item “for free.”
• Wrap and “give” it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Value of giving.
What is Gained:
• Empathy
• Generosity
steps: Set up a pretend shop.
Invite family to choose an item “for free.”
Wrap and “give” it.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Thank You Cards
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Make simple thank-you cards.
• Give them to family or friends.
• Talk about why gratitude matters.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practice appreciation.
What is Gained:
• Emotional growth
• Kindness
steps: Make simple thank
you cards.
Give them to family or friends.
Talk about why gratitude matters.

objective: To introduce the idea of planning before doing.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs make a plan before they start. 
 • Planning saves time and effort. 
 • Even play needs a plan!

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Build-a-Plan
Materials Needed: Blocks or LEGO.
Steps to Follow:
• Before building, draw what you want to make.
• Then build it with blocks.
• Compare plan vs. real build.
What Should Be Achieved:
Plan before action.
What is Gained:
• Thinking ahead
• Organization
steps: Before building, draw what you want to make.
Then build it with blocks.
Compare plan vs. real build.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
My Business Map
Materials Needed: Paper, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Draw a simple shop or service idea.
Steps to Follow: • Mark setup, talk, sell.
• Walk through the steps.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand business steps.
What is Gained:
• Process thinking
• Clarity
steps:
Draw a simple shop or service idea.
Steps to Follow:
Mark setup, talk, sell.
Walk through the steps.

objective: To practice speaking with purpose.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs explain ideas clearly.

activities.originalText:

• Practice fun voice tones.

Speaking for a purpose.

• Confidence
• Persuasive skills

• Give a simple “business pitch.”
• Smile, stand tall, and speak slow.
What Should Be Achieved:
Body language awareness.
What is Gained:
• Public speaking
• Expression control

objective: To help children learn about value.
explanation:
• Everything in business has a price. 
 • Prices depend on how useful or fun something is. 
 • Kids can learn to choose prices.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Price Tag Game
Materials Needed: Stickers, toys.
Steps to Follow:
• Assign play prices to toys.
• Talk about why one costs more.
• Rearrange and discuss.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand value.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Decision making
steps: Assign play prices to toys.
Talk about why one costs more.
Rearrange and discuss.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Guess the Price
Materials Needed: Real household items.
Steps to Follow:
• Show item and ask child to guess price.
• Say the real price.
• Talk about what makes things expensive or cheap.
What Should Be Achieved:
Relate worth to cost.
What is Gained:
• Estimation
• Real-world awareness
steps: Show item and ask child to guess price.
Say the real price.
Talk about what makes things expensive or cheap.

objective: To explore team spirit and roles.

Learn different tasks.
What is Gained:
• Flexibility
• Understanding variety

Build stories together.

• Improv thinking
• Listening

objective: To understand money pieces and their value.
explanation: • Money comes in coins and notes. • Each has a different value. • Entrepreneurs know how to count money.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:

Steps to Follow:
• Spread coins on a table.

Understand coin values.

• Number skills
• Money recognition
steps: Spread coins on a table.
Child matches each coin to value chart.

activities.originalText:

What Should Be Achieved:
Apply coin value in buying.
What is Gained:
• Basic transaction idea
• Role-play confidence
steps: Child “sells” items for coins.

objective: To value time and manage it for tasks.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:

activities.originalText:

What Should Be Achieved:
Relate time to action.
What is Gained:
• Time awareness
• Task linking

• Confidence

• Modify or decorate it to add value.

• Creativity
• Enhancement mindset

• Strategy thinking

• Learning attitude

objective: To learn how to present ideas quickly and clearly.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs often have just a minute to explain their idea. 
 • A quick, clear pitch helps attract interest and support. 
 • Practicing short speeches builds confidence.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Elevator Speech Time
Materials Needed: Timer, notepad.
Steps to Follow:
• Choose a product or business idea.
• Practice explaining it in 60 seconds.
• Use a timer and repeat for clarity.
What Should Be Achieved:
Clear and confident pitching.
What is Gained:
• Communication
• Time management
steps: Choose a product or business idea.
Practice explaining it in 60 seconds.
Use a timer and repeat for clarity.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pitch Gallery Walk
Materials Needed: Poster boards, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Write down the idea and a short pitch.
• Display them around a room.
• Walk around and read others' pitches.
What Should Be Achieved:
Exposure to different pitch styles.
What is Gained:
• Comparison skills
• Visual summarizing

objective: To understand how products are priced.
explanation:
• Price depends on cost, value, and audience. 
 • Entrepreneurs must balance profit and fairness. 
 • Thinking through pricing builds smart decision-making.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Price It Right
Materials Needed: Paper, fake money.
Steps to Follow:
• List items and guess their selling price.
• Discuss why prices are set that way.
• Try adjusting for high or low customers.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understanding of price logic.
What is Gained:
• Value judgment
• Economic thinking
steps: List items and guess their selling price.
Discuss why prices are set that way.
Try adjusting for high or low customers.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Budgeting Game
Materials Needed: Play money, product cards.
Steps to Follow:
• Each player gets a set amount of money.
• Decide what they can buy within that budget.
• Explain choices made.
What Should Be Achieved:
Simulated consumer decision-making.
What is Gained:
• Budgeting sense
• Logical planning
steps: Each player gets a set amount of money.
Decide what they can buy within that budget.
Explain choices made.

objective: To learn how entrepreneurs turn problems into solutions.
explanation:
• Many businesses start with solving a problem.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:

• Think about daily annoyances.
• Choose one and write how to solve it.
• Share idea with family.
What Should Be Achieved:
Awareness of real-life issues.
What is Gained:
• Problem analysis
• Design thinking

Share idea with family.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pitch the Fix

• Include what, why, and how.
• Present it as a pitch.
What Should Be Achieved:
Communication of solutions.
What is Gained:
• Presentation skill
• Confidence

objective: To understand customer testing.
explanation:
• Before launching, ideas are tested with real people. 
 • Getting feedback helps improve. 
 • Kids can play-test ideas in fun ways.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Try It Out
Materials Needed: Toy or paper product.
Steps to Follow:
• Make a basic version of an idea.
• Show it to 3 people.
• Ask what they liked or didn’t.
What Should Be Achieved:
Practicing feedback skills.
What is Gained:
• Listening
• Improvement mindset
steps: Make a basic version of an idea.
Show it to 3 people.
Ask what they liked or didn’t.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Feedback Form Fun
Materials Needed: Printed feedback form.
Steps to Follow:
• Create simple smiley scale form.
• Ask others to fill it after testing.
• Review responses.
What Should Be Achieved:
Analyzing feedback.
What is Gained:
• Data awareness
• Refinement skills

Ask others to fill it after testing.

objective: To analyze what makes a business succeed or fail.
explanation:
• Not all businesses thrive—some do better than others. 
 • Entrepreneurs must study what works and why. 
 • Learning from others helps plan smarter businesses.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Business Clue Hunt
Materials Needed: Internet access or printed business case examples.
Steps to Follow:
• Read a short business story.
• Identify what helped it succeed or caused it to fail.
• List key lessons learned.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identifying patterns in entrepreneurship.
What is Gained:
• Critical thinking
• Strategic awareness
materials: Internet access or printed business case examples.
steps: Read a short business story.
Identify what helped it succeed or caused it to fail.
List key lessons learned.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Business Makeover
Materials Needed: Drawing tools or digital slide tool.
Steps to Follow:
• Take a business that didn’t succeed.
• Redesign its plan or branding.
• Present the makeover idea.
What Should Be Achieved:
Reinvention thinking.
What is Gained:
• Creativity
• Problem-solving

steps: Take a business that didn’t succeed.

objective: To explore saving, spending, and investing as an entrepreneur.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs need strong financial habits. 
 • Kids can explore budgeting and tracking money. 
 • Saving and investing grow future ideas.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Budget Tracker
Materials Needed: Notebook or budget sheet.
Steps to Follow:
• Track weekly spending with allowance or play money.
• Categorize into needs, wants, and savings.
• Reflect on choices.
What Should Be Achieved:
Awareness of money flow.
What is Gained:
• Budgeting
• Value analysis

• Decide how much to invest and why.
• Share choices with others.

Simulated investing decisions.

• Risk evaluation
• Strategic judgment

objective: To apply the steps of design thinking to business.
explanation:
• Design thinking involves empathizing, defining, ideating, prototyping, and testing. 
 • It's used to solve real problems creatively. 
 • Kids can try the full cycle through fun challenges.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Empathy Explorer
Materials Needed: Interview questions, notebook.
Steps to Follow:
• Interview someone about a challenge they face.
• Write down what they feel, need, and want.
• Use this to define a design problem.
What Should Be Achieved:
Step one of design thinking.
What is Gained:
• Listening
• Problem framing
steps: Interview someone about a challenge they face.
Write down what they feel, need, and want.
Use this to define a design problem.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Prototype Challenge
Materials Needed: Building blocks, paper, tape.
Steps to Follow:
• Build a solution to the defined problem.
• Test it with a friend or adult.
• Improve based on feedback.
What Should Be Achieved:
Design thinking in action.
What is Gained:
• Iterative learning
• Creative confidence
steps: Build a solution to the defined problem.
Test it with a friend or adult.
Improve based on feedback.

objective: To compare entrepreneurship from past, present, and future.

• Business has changed over time—from barter to online stores. 
 • Knowing history helps plan the future. 
 • Kids can imagine what businesses might look like tomorrow.

activities.originalText:
Business Timeline
Materials Needed: Timeline template, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Place key types of businesses on a timeline.
• Add images or symbols.
• Discuss how tools and markets evolved.
What Should Be Achieved:
Seeing business as an evolving journey.
What is Gained:
• Historical insight
• Big-picture thinking

Visualizing future trends.

• Futuristic imagination
• Visionary thinking

objective: To introduce the idea of a Minimum Viable Product (MVP).
explanation:
• An MVP is the simplest version of a product. 
 • It’s a test to see if an idea works. 
 • Helps avoid waste and improve early.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Just Enough
Materials Needed: Paper, crayons.
Steps to Follow:
• Think of a business idea.
• Draw only the most important feature.
• Ask a friend if they’d use it.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify MVP essentials.
What is Gained:
• Prioritization
• Feedback loop
steps: Think of a business idea.

Ask a friend if they’d use it.

activities.originalText:

• Share MVP idea with family.
• Collect responses on likes and improvements.
What Should Be Achieved:
Early market testing.
What is Gained:
• Iterative thinking
• User perspective

objective: To teach how failure can lead to better ideas.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs often fail before succeeding. 
 • Learning from mistakes helps growth. 
 • Failure builds resilience.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Famous Fails
Materials Needed: Cards with failed products or ideas.
Steps to Follow:
• Read about failures (e.g. inventions, ideas).
• Guess why they failed and what improved later.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand failure as part of learning.
What is Gained:
• Growth mindset
• Risk tolerance
materials: Cards with failed products or ideas.
steps: Read about failures (e.g. inventions, ideas).

• Self-awareness
• Adaptability

• Note what you learned and how you'd do it differently.
What Should Be Achieved:
Reflect on learning from setbacks.
What is Gained:
• Self-awareness
• Adaptability

objective: To practice creating a powerful business pitch.
explanation:
• A pitch explains your idea in a short, clear way. 
 • It shows value, uniqueness, and impact. 
 • Builds public speaking and clarity.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
60-Second Pitch
Materials Needed: Timer, idea notes.
Steps to Follow:
• Pick a product idea.
• Create a 1-minute pitch to explain it.
• Time yourself and repeat to improve.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn concise pitching.
What is Gained:
• Public speaking
• Communication clarity
steps: Pick a product idea.
Create a 1
minute pitch to explain it.
Time yourself and repeat to improve.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pitch Parade
Materials Needed: Small audience of friends/family.
Steps to Follow:
• Present your pitch to the group.
• Take one question each.
What Should Be Achieved:
Build audience confidence.
What is Gained:
• Confidence
• Thinking on your feet
steps: Present your pitch to the group.

objective: To learn how trends influence business.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs look for trends to spot new ideas. 
 • Trends come from social changes, tech, or style. 
 • Timing is key to success.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Future Lens
Materials Needed: Magazines, online articles.
Steps to Follow:
• Read or browse for what's becoming popular.
• Circle interesting new products or behaviors.
What Should Be Achieved:
Identify emerging trends.
What is Gained:
• Market awareness
• Observation
steps: Read or browse for what's becoming popular.
Circle interesting new products or behaviors.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Trend to Idea
Materials Needed: Drawing paper, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Pick one trend spotted.
• Sketch a business based on that trend.
What Should Be Achieved:
Turn trend into opportunity.
What is Gained:
• Creative forecasting
• Design thinking
steps: Pick one trend spotted.
Sketch a business based on that trend.

objective: To understand how branding shapes identity.
explanation:
• Branding includes logo, colors, and message. 
 • A strong brand stands out and tells a story. 
 • It builds trust and recognition.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Logo Launch
Materials Needed: Paper, pencils, colored pens.
Steps to Follow:
• Think of a fun business idea.
• Design a logo and choose 2 brand colors.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand brand visuals.
What is Gained:
• Visual thinking
• Identity creation
steps: Think of a fun business idea.
Design a logo and choose 2 brand colors.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Slogan Spark
Materials Needed: Word cards, paper.
Steps to Follow:
• Create a catchy one-line slogan for your business.
• Make sure it matches the logo idea.
What Should Be Achieved:
Connect idea to message.
What is Gained:
• Wordplay
• Communication clarity
steps: Create a catchy one
line slogan for your business.
Make sure it matches the logo idea.

objective: To explore businesses that solve real-world problems.
explanation:
• Social entrepreneurs mix profit with purpose. 
 • They solve problems like hunger, pollution, or access. 
 • Makes business meaningful.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Problem Spotter
Materials Needed: News clippings or issue list.
Steps to Follow:
• Look at common problems around you.
• Pick one and think of a solution.
What Should Be Achieved:
See opportunities in challenges.
What is Gained:
• Empathy
• Social awareness
steps: Look at common problems around you.
Pick one and think of a solution.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Pitch for Good
Materials Needed: Note cards, timer.
Steps to Follow:
• Pitch your idea as if to help a community.
• Emphasize impact and need.
What Should Be Achieved:
Link profit to purpose.
What is Gained:
• Ethical thinking
• Idea presentation
steps: Pitch your idea as if to help a community.
Emphasize impact and need.

objective: To understand how entrepreneurship changed over time.
explanation:
• Businesses evolve with tech and culture. 
 • Past businesses inspire new ideas. 
 • Encourages timeline thinking.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Business Then & Now
Materials Needed: Printouts or sketches of old businesses.
Steps to Follow:
• Compare how a business worked 50 years ago vs. now.
• Discuss what changed and what stayed.
What Should Be Achieved:
Recognize evolution of business.
What is Gained:
• Historical view
• Comparative thinking
materials: Printouts or sketches of old businesses.
steps: Compare how a business worked 50 years ago vs. now.
Discuss what changed and what stayed.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Future Biz Sketch
Materials Needed: Drawing sheet, markers.
Steps to Follow:
• Imagine the same business 50 years in the future.
• Draw or explain how it might change.
What Should Be Achieved:
Forecast business transformation.
What is Gained:
• Imagination
• Futuristic thinking
steps: Imagine the same business 50 years in the future.
Draw or explain how it might change.

objective: To introduce the connection between entrepreneurship and finance.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs must manage earnings and costs. 
 • Smart money moves build strong businesses. 
 • Finance decisions shape future growth.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Budget Challenge
Materials Needed: Fake currency, list of costs.
Steps to Follow:
• Plan how to spend ₹100 on business needs.
• Choose between product, marketing, savings.
What Should Be Achieved:
Learn money decision-making.
What is Gained:
• Budget skills
• Prioritization
steps: Plan how to spend ₹100 on business needs.
Choose between product, marketing, savings.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
Profit Puzzle
Materials Needed: Simple math worksheet.
Steps to Follow:
• Calculate revenue and cost from a toy business.
• Subtract to find profit.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand profit formula.
What is Gained:
• Math fluency
• Business logic
steps: Calculate revenue and cost from a toy business.
Subtract to find profit.

objective: To explore what happens when a business ends or is sold.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs may sell or close a business. 
 • Exit strategies help prepare for transitions. 
 • Teaches closure and reinvention.

activities.name: Activity 1
activities.originalText:
Sale Scenario
Materials Needed: Role-play slips, fake contracts.
Steps to Follow:
• Role-play selling a business to a buyer.
• Decide what the new owner can change.
What Should Be Achieved:
Understand business transfer.
What is Gained:
• Negotiation skills
• Letting go
steps: Role
play selling a business to a buyer.
Decide what the new owner can change.

activities.name: Activity 2
activities.originalText:
What’s Next?
Materials Needed: Writing journal.
Steps to Follow:
• Write what you'd do after selling your business.
• Would you start again? Retire?
What Should Be Achieved:
Imagine post-business paths.
What is Gained:
• Future planning
• Entrepreneurial reflection
steps: Write what you'd do after selling your business.
Would you start again? Retire?
